review_title: It is a great organization, I am proud to work there
pros:
Good benefits, they promote from within, most employees honestly care about what they do. Most managers and members of leadership are fair and decent

You get to help kids and their families. It is an intangible, but it means something to a lot of people.
cons:
Annual review process can be less than ideal. There is an approval process for reviews and as long as your boss's boss knows you and what you contribute, you will probably get a fair review. If that is not the case or if that second level approver has their own ideas, even though they barely know you, you can end up with a lower score than you or your boss think you deserve. This will impact your bonus, your merit increase, your promotion prospects, etc. And there is no recourse.

There tends not to be a good work life balance. They have no problem with someone salaried working 10 and 12 hour days. But they do not factor this in when it is time for an evaluation.

They will hire you at as low a salary as they can, even when they think you are worth more. I know a lot of employers do this, it is not unusual, but that does not seem to coincide with the company ICARE values.

pros: There was absolutely no benefit to working in this position. Literally, they would not even provide coffee.

The leaders in the Infection Prevention and Control department leveraged Covid-19 to accomplish personal and departmental goals. Nepotism and favoritism towards tenured, but clearly low performing employees was rampant and difficult to walk into every day. While the organization was telling us to work from home during Covid, empty threats would be made to the Infection Prevention and Control staff regarding their attendance. This was done to appease the portion of the team that was required to be in attendance. The whole department was a mess and I would highly advise staying away from this group.

review_title: Great place for work-life balance, but can be slow if you want to advance your career
pros: Very kind and genuine coworkers all across CHOP that truly value your wellbeing. Many coworkers have been at CHOP for years (low turnover rate). Great place for work life balance (at least on the non-clinical side). Great mission that empowers you to continue your work. You also get insight on the inside scope in regards to Philadelphia's happenings because it tends to affect healthcare. Vacation / sick days (what we lump into Paid Personal Leave) is really generous compared to other companies. I truly think this is a great place to work if you want a purposeful job that allows you time to pursue life outside of work. However, if you are determined to advance your career in the shortest time possible, this might not be the place for you.
cons: Projects can move at a slow pace because there's so many factors involved. Also, recognition can be tough; often managers who oversees a project are recognized instead of the people who actually did the work. Pay is definitely 25% lower than at a private company. Promotion is often slow and not widely given.

review_title: Facilities & general conditions are great, management is terrible
job_title: Animal Care Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Hours are (6-2:30) but you can also work 7-3:30. Lots of PTO (you accrue 2 days a month to start, but the longer you work there, the more you get). You also get a $1 raise every year, and you get a raise when you get the ALAT certification. I've also heard HR undersells the amount you'll actually get paid when starting as a new tech, so it's possible you'll get more than you think. They are well supplied, well organized, and the actual work is good. You can opt to work the weekend shift so you'd work Sat-Wednesday with Thursday/Friday off, but you can do regular Monday-Friday if they have a designated weekend team in place already. They try to balance out the work and the schedule changes fairly frequently so if you don't like what you have, you can change it.
cons: Management is terrible, make sure you're ok with that before coming in. It takes 2-3 months minimum (often longer) to get a temp or replacement. Because of that, you end up short staffed all the time and you have to pick up the slack and make sure everything still gets done even if you're literally at half staff for a week+. There is also a lot of flexibility given to people who have been around a long time, since staff quit a lot due to the management. Newer staff often get stuck with more work. Expect to see staff putting in their two weeks pretty regularly and to have unexpected work loads hit you when people leave or call out (which is a common problem too).

review_title: Not a friendly place to work in research
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
If you’re a salaried employee, you did not have to clock in or out.

The pay range is transparent, the hospital shared with employees every year about the overall pay raises and pay grades. I think you can now search for them on their career site. But for you to get a raise or promotion depended entirely on your manager and the rating they gave you at your annual review.

Health care benefits are so-so for adults (think similar to the affordable care act), but great if you have a child. I’ve heard that most employees stay for the benefits for their children.
cons:
Hostile and toxic work environment. Low pay for the industry (low 20s/hr). The negative reviews are true. I was in research, be cautious of working for the group that started with 3 words from the 4th letter of the alphabet.

Your experience will vary because of the many research groups and departments, it’s a hit or miss. That’s why it’s kind of hard to find actual specific reviews when you apply for a job with a specific team.
What I noticed was for my department, they hired a majority of younger people, the 21-30 y/o demographic. My inner team was 95% women, it was not good. The middle aged women who were in management were very cliquey, catty, judgemental, and had high school mentalities, despite most having master degrees.

When they noticed that you do not fit their mold or their idea of an ideal employee, they would build a case to get you fired (documentation, holding meetings to talk about their concerns). Don’t bother with HR either, they’re on the side of management and from the looks of it after checking older reviews this hasn’t changed and will not.

They hold people who are incompetent in what they are supposed to be knowledgeable about on a pedestal mainly because they like them, a lot. So the persons can continue to screw up and management will continue to brush the mistakes under the rug. And for some, help them climb the career ladder and push them all the way to management, even though they do not deserve it at all. 
You can also bring your concerns many times to management about different things (employees not actually doing work, crucial or continuous mistakes that were made) and they will either say they acknowledge it, excuse it, or flat out ignore you even if you have documentation.

Think twice before applying.

-REFUSE TO HIRE MORE PEOPLE EVEN THOUGH WE ARE SHORT STAFFED-those business people look at the numbers and determine we have enough staff. though they keep texting me on my days off asking to do overtime because they don't want to hire more people. always pulling from CSO (float pool) to meet needs which doesn't even solve the issue most of the time when they still don't give us enough nurses. i've had plenty of shifts with unsafe ratios and charge RNs with a full assignment. it's a slap on the face to the people actually doing the job to say we are fully staffed...so very insulting
-you are just a number-they can and will replace you in a second. 
-WORST MANAGEMENT-they only care about making money don't care about you personally. they do my reviews and have never even seen a cent of my nursing ability. disorganized and only looks out for the company you as an individual are useless to them
-parking is the worst. why should i pay to go to work? make that make sense please. plus that shuttle takes FOREVER to take since there is always a line for it, making most people late. you have to be over an hour early to get on one of those things on time.
-not about the patients-like i said in the title, this place only cares about money. they do not hire enough staff on purpose, don't give out raises like they should, move people around like checker pieces to meet their demands. they are creating an entire new hospital but don't give their current staff raises. that is sad. and then they wonder why people leave for penn medicine or leave for travel nursing
-nurse residency program is the biggest joke...only do it for magnet recognition not even because they want to help you as the nurse. they "paused" nurse residency due to the pandemic and then had us go back at it after like 8 months without acknowledging there was a giant break in between. not to mention, starting nurse residency after the first year of nursing passed is POINTLESS...so many people quit in my cohort due to lack of support and being tossed around like trash because of COVID and chop claiming they "have no money" while they build a new hospital and hand out all the employees new iphones. 
-pay is low compared to other hospitals

pros:
- Challenging work as CHOP tries to stay ahead. You get to work on a lot of interesting projects.
- While it can get old, the overall mission of helping children (even indirectly) is great. CHOP really does care highly about their patients and their safety.
- Good Benefits (401b, pension, vacation, tuition reimbursement, and insurance).
- Work/Life balance is what you make of it, but while you're at work, you will be swamped.
- Management doesn't micro-manage you (this is not true of all managers, but mine is great).
- Noticed a recent change in tide as managers are being more closely examined for their effectiveness and supervision skills over employees.
cons:
- CHOP takes on way too much work and everyone is spread thin. (CHOP rarely says No to a request).
- Unless you get a promotion or another position, there not much of a raise.
- Very little room for career growth unless someone higher up decides to leave.
- Decisions take forever because everyone under the sun needs to be included and no one wants to speak up against one another.
- The need for perfection is a detriment.
- There can be a lot of red tape and hoops to jump through to get decision made or get to the right person.
- CHOP abides strongly to the chain of command, to a fault.
- At times, management tends to worry more about client happiness to the detriment of their employee happiness.
- CHOP can be very de-compartmentalized.

pros: CHOP is a great company to work for. The benefits are amazing, almost no overtime at all, a ton of time off, people are nice. The location for finance is great, right outside city hall, cool during holiday time since it is in the Macy's building with the light show. The CEO truly does a lot to inspire staff at all levels, in all lines of work. My boss genuinely cared about me and my career.
cons: To be blunt: coming from public accounting I was incredibly bored. I was basically a glorified secretary, ran errors, and had to go to the post office often. Huge change from public accounting, often felt like I wasn't using my brain and wondered why I was hired as I felt there was very little work to do. There is almost no room for upward mobility, unless you start at manager level and above. In the beginning it seemed exciting that people had been there for 30+ years, but really, they just don't fire people they should. Very little flexibility, truely a 9-5, people would definitely notice if you showed up at 9:05. The building is super rundown and dirty, had black dust on my desk when the air conditioning went on. Also, it is business attire 4/5 days, relaxed dressed for summer.

review_title: Love the Mission and the Work
pros: First and foremost the mission; flexible working options (typically 1 day a week ability to work from home); medical benefits are amazing (especially if you have children and use the CHOP Care Network locations); plenty of vacation days even when just starting; a great working environment (great team, management truly cares about us in HR, the facilities are top notch, very well resourced); plenty of opportunity for professional development (it’s not only highly encouraged but it’s weaved into the culture); a team of high performers; HR is heavily consulted and relied upon; high levels of autonomy; growing and stable; work life balance is at the forefront
cons: The equivalent of the 401k is just ok; the volume of work can feel crushing at times (mitigated by Resources and support available to us and the emphasis on unplugging and work/life balance...I love how we all are swamped with work but it’s understood and leaders understand...so while it can get overwhelming or intense there a sense of understanding since we all feel the pain); the uncertain healthcare/insurance environment leads to running leaner than the amount of work reasonably should permit (this isn’t just a CHOP thing though); each department can almost feel like it’s own business so there can at times be lack of alignment in processes or procedures that should otherwise be aligned at the enterprise level; parking can be expensive

pros: CHOP has a mission you can feel good about, and has great name recognition.  If you work here, be prepared to answer tons of questions when people learn you work at CHOP.  During my tenure, I was involved in a lot of project work, had complete autonomy and very little micro-management.  Leadership was supportive of upgrading old legacy gear, which made my job easier.  CHOP has a large array of technology and isn't afraid to spend money when it makes sense.  This is a place you can definitely develop your tech skills.  As an engineer, my hours were very flexible and life revolves around train schedules.
cons: HR is a mess at CHOP - benefits mistakes, payroll problems, onboarding issues, etc - anything HR related is a disarray and takes 10x longer to resolve than any other organization I've worked.  This is a heavily political environment - very similar to government.  Projects have high budgets, but move VERY slowly, so the pace is something that requires an adjustment.  IT has a lot of engineers, many who are lifers that bring very little value to the overall mission.  Prepare to deal with very challenging personalities, some of which will make your work-life very difficult.  This is a non-profit, so the benefits and competition are weak compared to other organizations.  The review process is very weak and based on almost unobtainable criteria that make little sense.

pros: Pros for working at CHOP include Salary, PTO, Networking
cons: Cons for working at CHOP include dept politics, voice is not heard

job_title: Director, Computer Services in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Consistent, reasonable feedback. Supportive management. Excellent benefits and competitive salaries. Input consistently requested and, when possible, actually acted upon. Upper management has a sane & consistent message and goals - both short & long-term. You actually see the impact of your work. Management makes sure that you feel that your work is helping to make sure that kids get the medical support they need AND that their families are supported as well, The kids are frequently children with terrible. debilitating conditions & the hospital treats the entire family, making sure that the parents as well as siblings get the physical & the psychological support they ALL need to help the patient get better. The management structure makes sure that employees - from medical staff to fundraisers to administrative support - all know exactly HOW their work  contributes to the overall goal of curing sick kids, while ensuring that healthy kids STAY healthy.
cons: The workload is very, VERY heavy. Medical staff are the stars of the hospital - and deservedly so. But they require a large staff of people behind them, making sure that the hospital functions as smoothly as possible. While management knows that these people will rarely get the attention they deserve  (& the staff knows that as well), ensuring sufficient staffing levels was sometimes a struggle.

pros: Very good company to work for

review_title: Good science environment, but lousy bureaucracy
pros: Good benefits, progressive atmosphere, great collaborators.  Lots of resources at CHOP to do great research, and you have access to all Penn resources as well.
cons: I like working at CHOP.  The science here is not the problem, it's great.  The issue is lousy IT department that makes using your computer impossible, gouging you (16 dollars for 3 hours!) for parking if you can't take the train one day, and horrible super expensive cafeteria with no close alternatives.  For example, if I have an early meeting and there's no convenient train, and I don't pack a lunch, it may cost me 35 dollars just to show up to work that day.  On top of that, they just built another parking garage, and instead of letting us use the old one they cone it off so we can't park there.  So they have 100's of spots sitting empty but they charge you anyway.

review_title: Excellent Peds Work! All other rumors are true.
pros: Great advancements in the field of Pediatrics!!! Really creative and innovative techniques. Excellent brand name and world renowned recognition as the nations first and oldest hospital dedicated solely for children. Great partnerships with local businesses, especially the toy drive and prom.
cons: Diversity is not represented at all past the supervisor/manager level, CHOP is not representational of the popluation which it serves, for an institution of this size and stature it is very disappointing. On the research side CHOP is doing great things however operations is a nightmare. Typical corporate philosophy...it's not what you know rather who you know. Currently matching 25% of 50% of your eligible contributions. Only physicians have voices.

review_title: Great for patients, horrible for employees
pros: Extensive training given, very reassuring given the high risk pediatric environment.  Clean and organized work environment.  Very good benefits.  Some opportunity for promotion.
cons: Almost no work-life consideration from managers.  Made to feel guilty just for taking a sick day.  Extreme micro-managing with almost no connection between mangers and front line staff.  Suggestions are unwelcome and rarely heeded if you can even get management to listen.  Employees treated like workers not contributors which means employees rarely feel invested in what they are doing.  You do not feel like an valued member of the team, just another worker to fill a shift.  This leads to a lot of staff turnover which management doesn't seem to care about cause nothing changes.  Salary is lower than regional average.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The people who organize everything mean well and put a lot of effort into scheduling orientation seminars and want you to feel welcome, positive hospital mission, patient safety is a high priority
cons: They have no commitment to keeping you in the nurse residency and can let you go at any time, many different preceptors, preceptors often don't really want to be in the role, high turnover,  little positive feedback from preceptors, no positive feedback from management, nursing staff can be catty and rude to new hires, preceptors can be impatient, you only sign an "agreement" and not a true contract for nurse residency so they can let you go at any time without due process (READ THE FINE PRINT), low pay compared to other Philadelphia hospitals and workload, unrealistic expectations for new hires (you either get it quickly in the first 2-3 weeks or you could be fired with no true due process or writeups)

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant I in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
I worked as a research assistant in a large (40+ personnel) NIH R01 funded lab. This was one of the most enjoyable and satisfying jobs I have ever had, although many of my experiences will not necessarily generalize to other research groups or departments at CHOP.

CHOP itself is an exciting place to work, and it tends to attract very competent and motivated employees (with a few exceptions; see below). Collaborating with other researchers at CHOP was always a pleasure for this reason. If you work in a field that CHOP executives consider high priority, internal funding is generously given for research equipment, staff, and other resources.
cons: CHOP bureaucracy is frustratingly slow, and can result in long delays of simple tasks; e.g. purchasing approved items such as office supplies can take months; making small changes to your group's website can take weeks to be approved; certain departments never return phone calls.

review_title: High profile departments get a pass on professionalism

pros:

Intellectual community

Lack of transparency about salaries and career trajectories.
Employee morale is low (per yearly surveys), but it's not addressed by management.

review_title:
CH





CHOP: A Terrific Facility for Learning; Not So Much for Prosperity
job_title: Physical Therapist I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It is an institution that prides itself on being the best. Its employees are very competent and strive to be the very best that they can be, however, are many times overlooked by senior management. It is a great institution for learning and growing as a clinician, especially if you are of the type A persuasion.
cons: Senior management, as in any facility can have the tendency to be exceedingly political. They can pick and choose with whom they will fraternize and who will be promoted. It is unfortunate, but it still happens everywhere, even at the top pediatric hospital.

pros: Amazing and inspiring staff. Definitely the best and brightest in the country and I am honored to work with them. You will see amazing thing, but also heartbreaking things; be prepared! My co workers are like my second family!
cons: There is not as much interdisciplinary communication as I am used to. Not sure if medical people value nursing staff. Docs are not very independent and seem to need a lot of support from nursing staff to function; they don't seem to be able to "do" anything for themselves an it appears they want to be waited on by nursing staff and they do not really act thankful for the assistance. Pay for nursing is poor...much more money is being offered in Wilmington De (the "other" children's hospital) and they have free parking!

job_title: CHOP Foundation Employee in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Saving and improving the lives of kids is the best reason to work for CHOP -- they have an excellent mission.
cons: Employees aren't treated as well as patients, families, and donors. Over the years, CHOP has become more about making money, which it's all for a good cause, but they save their compassion for the kids and act like staff are replaceable parts of a machine instead of people. Benefits are decent, but could be better. Management is all about results and not the individual.

pros: Flexible. Min. 16 hours/4 week period. Consistently up to 40 hours/week available hours. Can make your own schedule. Get to float around the hospital to different units. Good experience with a variety of patient populations, cultures and disease processes. Night and weekend differential. 401kB retirement matching. Ideal job when you're in school.
cons: Can be boring at times. Difficult to meet people because of the flexibility, floating to different units all the time and the safety huddles tend to clicky among psych techs. Rest of hospital staff doesn't think sitters do anything, which can be true. Some sitters don't do anything. Awkward to be assigned to a room when there is no need for you because their parents are there, but you have to stay anyway.

review_title: Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine Does not Promote
pros: The pay is good compared to other hospitals outside of the city. The work is interesting.
cons: CHOP doesn't seem to want to invest in current employees. There is a wealth of talent in the department, but whenever there is an opening, there is more emphasis on outside candidates. There is a "career ladder", but the same standards are not applied to everyone. It seems that if you threaten to quit or complain, you don't have to work as hard for your promotion.

review_title: Research at CHOP is both innovative and collaborative
job_title: Research Technician II in Phila, PA
pros: Working in research at CHOP is intellectually satisfying and awards you the opportunity to work with many amazing, reputable researchers both at CHOP and Penn. Work-life balance is great; as in many academic settings, hours can be flexible and productivity depends on the time you put in.
cons: Compensation should be higher considering city living expenses and there is no direct path to promotions.  As in many large institutions, if you need help that requires you to go outside your department, expect your request to take a lot of time and go through many people with very narrow job descriptions--finding the one person that can actually help you is always tough.

pros: Having worked in the main hospital, the Wood Center, and the Abrasion Research buildings, I can say that every area of CHOP exudes positivity in the workplace. Everyone truly wants to be there because it's the #1 children's hospital in the nation. It is also the #1 children's hospital because everyone truly want to work there.
cons: It is often difficult to get information updated, such as a new phone number or address, through HR. My checks were  mailed to my old residence for almost 2 months before the error was finally corrected.

pros: Respectable pay.  Mission is without fault.  Generally beautiful facilities.  Have a ton of money.
cons: Politics.  Preach questioning authority and challenge assumptions, but in practice was go with the flow herd mentality.  HR is a shell/holding company of outsourced firms and less than helpful.  Board got away from old time conservative Philadelphia money and too corporate (Comcast, Vnaguard, J&J), so its all about mergers, profit margin, and beating the competition.

review_title: Loved the work & people; loathed the unnecessary politics
pros:
- Great place to work if you have children.
- Co-workers and colleagues were fantastic.
- Benefits package was pretty outstanding for the region.
- Knowing the work contributed to a much larger and positive picture made it easy to go in and get the job done.
cons:
- In the time that I was there, I watched the department degenerate into a heavily political environment.
- Good people with double-digit years of service left the organization as a result of the political environment; major red flag.

pros: So far I've enjoyed it here. Everyone is nice, and the environment is just really supportive - my supervisor and director actively take an interest in trying to help me figure out my interests and advance my career. It's a laid-back workplace and everyone considers the work-life balance to be sacred, so I'm not expected to answer emails on the weekends or anything like that.
cons: Everyone works on their own little teams, so I rarely get to meet new people unless they're specifically introduced to me. So even though it's a small office, it's not necessarily tight-knit (at least from my point of view).

job_title: Adolescent Case Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Many resources for employees, 25 days PTO,  robust medical/dental/vision options. Nationally renowned institution with name recognition. Tons of independence within departments: often times CHOP feels like a neighborhood and each department is its own entity. Overall the institution and its leadership is politically progressive and wants to make groundbreaking changes in the field of pediatrics.
cons: Again, depends on the department. Overall, there is a pervasive old-school culture that prioritizes seniority and credentials. Complete deference is expected from new hires and sharing novel ideas can be viewed as insubordinate.  Any respect from colleagues must be earned, usually over many years. Sometimes it seems like being cutting-edge is more important to CHOP than providing compassionate, high-quality care.

pros: The organization has a well deserved international reputation as the best pediatric hospital in the world.  The clinical and research teams drive the technology teams to excel, and demand more and more to serve the patients and their families.
cons: The organization preaches "work-life balance" but from my observation this was more public relations than philosophy.  First level managers and below were considered completely replaceable.   Leadership's agenda was not conducive to retention of skilled employees.

job_title: Office Coordinator in Upper Darby, PA
pros: Diverse patient population, difference you make in patient lives, wealth of knowledge available on array of diagnosis
cons: Many advocate that employees further education but make it impossible to advance in the organization. One's title is the driving force to get things done. Some employees are very disrespectful to one another. In certain departments  money is the ultimate focus.

job_title: Executive Secretary II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: you are surrounded by smart and driven people (non management level), beautiful campus, mission driven organization
cons: Benefits are not competitive, management is awful and makes terrible decisions that do not benefit employees, you are often made to feel like its a privilege to be working there and that the company doesn't value your contributions. CEO is a stepford wife who cares about appearances versus and is not genuine.

review_title: A challenging place to work both professionally & personally
pros: You feel like you are making a difference when you are in the presence of patients & take pride in where you work.

review_title: Great Place for Medical Staff but No Room for Growth in Research
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Working for the number 1 children's hospital in the country is awesome. The company works hard to be such and this instills a lot of pride in the employees
cons: In research, there is not a lot of room for growth and there is very little appreciation for research team members. Faculty only looks for working cogs for their own promotion without promoting staff members.

job_title: Emergency Department RN/Charge Nurse in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great place to work, love my job. MD/RN respect and collaboration is excellent.  Nurse to patient ratio allows you to safely take care of your patients and give them top quality care.
cons: CHOP needs to open an inpatient psych ward. The increase number of these kids we are seeing in out department is incredible. As one of the top pediatric hospitals in the country with all it's advancements in child healthcare and research, they need to start taking better care of this population of growing patients.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Consistently higher salaries than Penn. Lots of talented faculty.  Many projects are quite cutting edge and could have an impact on children's health.
cons: Highly fractured research informatics community - there were at least 8 groups doing the same thing as us with no sharing of code. Research is compromised by the hospital IT infrastructure. Managers are not given control over budgets. Turf wars are common - usually the most cutthroat player wins. Poor communication is endemic.

pros: Prestigious name to have on your resume. Good benefits. Not a bad place to work. Over all its a good environment.
cons: Can be very political. They combine all sick time, personal time and vacation time into one pot and this time accrues on a biweekly basis versus. Work and life balance can be a challenge.

review_title: The Best Children's Hospital in the country!
pros: The culture is family centered care. Highly competent physicians and nurses work together as a group to provide the best care to Children bringing happiness to their lives. Very well organized at several levels. Overall, you will be very happy to work her and feel privileged to be the part of something that one of the best in the world!
cons: There is an academic pressure to perform and long bureaucratic processes to get relatively simple things done which can be frustrating.

job_title: Research Postdoctoral Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Good place to do research. Benefits are good. People are nice and co-operate well. Excellent infrastructure for research. If you want to do research, you can not go wrong wih choosing CHOP.
cons: Career prospects for PhD level scientists are not good. It is not fault of CHOP because in general biomedical scientists are facing high underemployment.

review_title: Company with good reputation for the healthcare they provide, but not necessarily to work
pros: Facilities are up-to-date and so the working environment is nice.  The mission to provide services to children via medical care, therapy, and to some extent medical research revolving around children is a good cause to be involved in.
cons: During onboarding CHOP gloats a little bit to new employees about its stellar reputation as an employer mostly because they have a high # of applicants they turn away, aka selectivity.  Only after onboarding can a new employee glean a lot of glaring problems within different departments, areas.  HR will tell employees CHOP is great because they get benefits, the are "in the club" and now they can apply for promotions and other jobs internally.  Secretly, Recruitment teams (which cover specialty areas within the hospital) that receive resumes for transfers/promotions/new job applications internally are chummy with Managers and so if you apply for a job at CHOP your managers will know.  Rumors about certain managers also fly around that if you are trying to transfer, managers will find a way to terminate you before you can ever secure a new job.  Thus the typical retention mechanisms at CHOP seem to be to scare people into staying in their job and doing it so that the hospital has less staff turnover.  I have yet to talk to anyone at CHOP that related a story of a pro-employee retention strategy which is typically to find out an employee is considering other jobs and to raise their salary or restructure their job to make them happier in a current position.

pros:
Incredibly dedicated front line staff
Good benefits package
Opportunities for growth
Reputation
Pockets of culture that supports teamwork and values optimizing care for patients
cons: Complete disconnect t between leadership and front line staff.  Focus is so much on profits and finances that the leadership seems to forget it's the clinical staff that are the reason patients come here.  They have bought their own hype about being number one.

pros: Best job I ever had. I met all of my best friends here. The benefits are exemplary.The pay was good.
cons: Mandatory flu shots put certain people at risk and hiring practices are ineffective.

pros: The pros of working at CHOP is that the salary is very competitive for an hourly-waged worker and the benefits are pretty good. The environment is also positive and aesthetically pleasing in the main areas. Depending on the unit, you have flexibility with your schedule and are not micro-managed.
cons: The challenge of working here is that job responsibilities in administration, particularly nursing administration, are unrealistic. It appears that supervision does not have a genuine understanding of all it it takes to support a unit of 150 or more staff . The job entails the bi-weekly processing of payroll, completing a 4-8 week schedule for nursing staff which in some cases include more than 300+ nurses on a unit, expense reports, random or regular supply ordering, responding to staff inquiries, special projects, the upkeep of employee files --- the list goes on-and-on. Depending on the unit that you work, overtime is not an option and working from home to stay on top of things is ousted. The expectation is that you have a 40 hour work week, and that's all you have to get it done. Period. If you fall behind or if you are unable to absorb all of the duties (or should I say, the ones supervision deems important), expect a PIP to be your next reality and more than likely a shrugged shoulder and good bye! The position can become extremely stressful particularly if you are a person who strives hard to stay on top of things only to see it's virtually impossible. If you take off a few days, expect to fall behind because there is no back up for you when you're gone. If you are a non-union employee, your raises are performance based, and of course if your role is underestimated or devalued then you won't be adequately compensated for your efforts.

pros: Everything we do at CHOP  supports families and patients when they are at their most vulnerable. It really is a very special type of work and takes  caring individuals to help meet the need of the patients .Employees can also take pride in the fact that “hospitals are the backbones of communities."
cons: Working with co-workers who do not like their job and constantly complains. Having a bad attitude  and gossiping can make your job difficult.

pros: Assessable accessible to all public transportation, some of the staff are really great people to work with. Some of the management are really difficult and hard to get along with.
cons: The work environment is kind of thick. Not all the staff is happy to work there however they need a job so they work there. Some of the management want you to go out of above and beyond without paying you for all your duties they talk down to you sometimes you have to be able to have thick skin

pros: This place is full of brilliant doctors and colleagues. Meaning is built right in to your job. CHOP lets you know they care about you as an employee. The positive atmosphere mixed with the chance to do real good for others is intoxicating. I will go back, if there is a good fit for me in the future.
cons: Pay can be low in some positions. It is also difficult to advance, since so many people do not want to leave.

review_title: CHOP makes it easy to go to work every day!
job_title: IS Developer I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: What's great about CHOP is knowing that whatever you do, you're part of an organization that helps sick kids get well.  The benefits are great and the workforce is dedicated and positive.  There's certainly a lot of prestige attached to working here, as well.  You can be disabled, a person of color, LGBT, or any other minority and find welcome.
cons: The pay is well under market value.  You cannot smoke or use tobacco and will be tested at hire.  There is rather a lot of bureaucracy which can be stifling.

pros: Great research facilities, great faculty and staff, labs are generally well funded and open, productive environments, solid benefits, easily accessible by public transportation.
cons: My only problem with working at CHOP is more of an issue with the state of Philadelphia's layout and highways than the actual hospital/research buildings. The campus is easily accessible by train, but there is VERY limited parking with a waiting list that has a wait time of several years. I unfortunately, do not live close to a train line and I have to pay for an expensive park and ride service which is often inconvenient.

pros: CHOP delivers excellent care to children, and holds themselves to very high standards.  They have a wide range of services for children.  Benefits are good for employees, lots of perks like employee discounts.
cons: There have been many recent changes to weekend requirements that have required more senior nurses to have to go back to working more frequent weekends.

pros: There are some great nurses /doctors in main hospital working with kids. Occasional free food in office.

review_title: One of the best places to work???  Don't believe it for a minute!!
pros: Phenomenal benefits with low employee copays.  Competitive salaries.  Convenient to public transportation.  Stable company making consistently high profit. Worthy mission.
cons: While CHOP looks like a good place to work on paper, the reality is an entirely different story.  I'm consistently amazed at how they manage to keep the truth from getting out and maintain this "top-notch" image that they have, and so glad to have found a forum such as this to warn people.  I cannot speak for EVERY department there as it is a huge institution; I can only tell you what my particular department was like.  I am reaching to find a word that could even come close to describing the utter insanity, incompetence and abuse that went on with the higher level of management in my department.  People were hired without the specific experience/background they needed in order to be effective in their leadership positions, but their abuse of power was rampant.  Employees were randomly targeted and SEVERELY mistreated.  Hard-working staff was treated degradingly and condescendingly; pummeled with workloads that were not humanly possible to complete; harrassed by non-stop emails and other communication; and never given praise or appreciation for outstanding efforts, or rewarded with well-earned raises.  There was no place for home-work balance whatsoever; long hours were expected.  There seems to be no recourse for any of this, either, as everything at CHOP is highly political, and Human Resources is completely ineffective and bureaucratic.  I would not work there again if it were the last employer on earth, and the horrors that I encountered and endured will remain with me for years to come.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I enjoyed working with my co-workers who are so dedicated to helping children.
cons: The clinical research environment at CHOP is incredibily disorganized. Research teams are very siloed, so if the team you are hired on is toxic it's not easy to talk to someone in administration. HR appears to be indifferent - in response to a request for an exit interview I was sent a generic survey.

pros: This is a great hospital to work for.  I feel they really take care of their employees.  I like the friendly atmosphere.  The patient is of highest priority here at CHOP. review_title: My experience has been so much more terrible working here than I could possibly ever imagine.
job_title: Research Technician I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It feels nice knowing that your work is helping children and many coworkers are wonderful people. There are decent benefits and if you have a good position, life can be very enjoyable here as it has a strong connection with Penn and attracts a dynamic international crowd of doctors and researchers.
cons: I had one of the worst experiences here and CHOP is 100% to blame for this. Right after starting, I had to report my boss for creating a sexually hostile work environment. I followed HR policy to report the abuse and protect a future international employee from leaving a job for one in which she could end up deported. I was first ignored for days because they have a system in place to try to hide any bad PR through a third party website. When I forced CHOP to take action, they handled the situation entirely wrong and caused a confrontation and for me to lose my job. I was treated with the utmost rudeness by the HR department for following company policy and reporting the inappropriate behavior. They then left me hanging for days while going on vacation. I had to continually push for them to step up and do their jobs in the HR department and was given no choice as to my next position. In the new position, I was not allowed to renegotiate my salary despite the job having far more work. I have been lied to several times about salary increases and have been given ten times more work and biohazard jobs that I never agreed to for less pay than was initially indicated for my first position. CHOP receives a large amount of money from researchers, so their behavior is basically unmonitored and they go unpunished for illegal actions. With the new job postings, you have no way of telling who the researcher is, so anyone could end up in a terrible situation like I did.  I also tried transferring within the company after 6 months in my new position like I was told I could, but am unable to because it is not in CHOP's best interest.

pros: Autonomy, high acuity, travel perks
cons: Horrible work life balance. Forced to work 8 hour shifts without our permission. Used to be 3/ 12 hour shifts. Now because everyone is quitting we have to work 4 shifts a week. Toxic and destructive coworkers. New leadership that is dictatorship and disruptive to unit.  Mandatory overtime. Disrespect for your personal time. Late dispatches for low acuity patients means you're out late every night. Write ups galore. Very high turnover.

review_title: Good place for junior level PhD scientists to come if they want to end their careers in academic research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Decent benefits for postdoctoral fellows. Good speakers and good seminars. Can also attend talks at UPenn.
cons: My experience at CHOP has been horrible. I had multiple competing offers at the time I interviewed and was recruited here with promises of promotions and opportunities to write grants; none of this materialized. From the door at orientation, scientific researchers aren't treated as though they're a part of CHOP. I've worked at many research hospitals before and never felt like this. If the PI you work for becomes abusive, there is no recourse (and this happens often-- many postdocs at CHOP, like most R1 institutes, seem to be H1B visa holders who are dependent on their PIs' good graces to stay in the country. PIs thus have total control; this can lead to an abusive climate towards all postdocs if left unchecked, and PI power is totally unchecked at CHOP). HR is utterly nonresponsive to scientific staff and CHOP neither offers nor encourages any mentoring, career guidance, or professional training opportunities outside of your PI. PIs don't seem to be given any basic management training either, and are allowed to lay off postdocs at will so there is always the threat of that regardless of your prior performance. As a woman, CHOP was also a terrible environment-- for instance, my PI constantly asked me about when/if I had plans to get pregnant and about other private matters. HR does nothing. I was promised a good work/life balance when I interviewed but after a few months, a consistent theme of my meetings with my PI was his frustration and disappointment that I was not working 80+ hours a week (without being paid any overtime, of course). I am a parent, so this is not possible. Furthermore, professionally, working those hours would have done nothing for my own career since I was treated like a tech to work on my PI's random ideas and grants-- rather than anything that would have furthered my own career. My PI also had major issues with my using my sick days when my young child became ill-- not something you might expect from a children's hospital? But presenteeism is part of the culture; quality of work and overall productivity is not taken into the equation. I wish I could go back in time; it was career suicide to come here, and I can't think of any postdoc at CHOP for whom it wouldn't be, given the absolute power PIs are given at CHOP, combined with the lack of mentoring and human resources.
